content.text: A spring is suspended from a clamp. Fig. 1.1 shows a pointer attached to the lower end of the spring
A student suspends loads of different weights from the spring and records the readings on the metre ruler
Calculate the maximum momentum of the car during the race
maximum momentum =   .........
State the feature of Fig. 2.2 that represents the distance travelled by the car
Determine the distance travelled by the car in the first 6.5 s
distance =   .........
the car decelerates
the deceleration of the car is not constant
The parachute opens at 6.5s and the car decelerates
Describe how Fig. 2.2 shows that, after 6.5 s:
Describe the energy transfer that takes place as the car slows down
A drag car is a racing car that is powered by a rocket engine
A drag car accelerates uniformly from rest until it reaches the finishing line. The engine is then switched off and a parachute opens. The car decelerates until it stops
Fig. 2.1 shows a drag car decelerating after a race
This drag car has a mass of \(1400\mathrm{kg}\)
Fig. 2.2 is the speed–time graph for the car during a race on a straight horizontal track
The car reaches its maximum speed of \(130 \text{m/s}\) at a time of \(6.5 \text{s}\)
Define the moment of a force and describe the effect that it measures
Explain what is meant by centre of gravity
The weight of the block is \(1.3 \times 10^{7} \text{N}\)
Calculate the moment of the weight of the block about corner X
moment of weight =   .........
A large rectangular block of stone has a square base of side \(3.4 \text{m}\). Fig. 3.1 shows the block at rest on a horizontal surface
The block is of uniform density and the centre of gravity G is at its centre
The block shown in Fig. 3.1 is in equilibrium
State the two different conditions that apply when an object is in equilibrium
Describe an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of aluminium. You may draw a diagram
Include in your answer:
• the measurements made
• any equations needed
Explain why, after a short time, the dish and the water are the same temperature
Explain, in terms of its particles, why the aluminium expands as the boiling water is poured into the dish
The water in the dish evaporates
Explain, in terms of the water molecules, what is meant by evaporation
An aluminium dish is initially at room temperature. Boiling water is poured into the aluminium dish as shown in Fig. 4.1
Calculate the wavelength of the sound wave
wavelength =   .........
State a typical value for the speed of sound in air
Calculate the frequency of the sound from the loudspeaker
frequency =   .........
Explain whether the sound from the loudspeaker is audible to a human with normal hearing
Another loudspeaker produces a sound of wavelength \(0.40 \text{m}\). Sound from the loudspeaker reaches a sound absorbing surface with a gap of width \(0.80 \text{m}\) at the centre
Fig. 5.1 shows the arrangement
Explain whether it is possible to detect sound from the loudspeaker at either point J or at point K
point J
point K
A loudspeaker produces a sound wave in air. The distance between the centre of a compression and the centre of a neighbouring rarefaction is \(0.10 \text{m}\)
Define potential difference (p.d.)
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the supply is \(E\)
Describe how the p.d. across the thermistor can be determined using the reading on the voltmeter
State what has happened to the light intensity incident on the LDR and the temperature of the thermistor
intensity of incident light on LDR:
temperature of thermistor:
Explain what happens to the reading on the voltmeter
The resistance of the LDR decreases and the resistance of the thermistor increases

A potential divider is made by connecting a light-dependent resistor (LDR) and a thermistor in series. Fig. 6.1 shows the potential divider, a voltmeter and a direct current (d.c.) power supply connected into a circuit
The voltmeter measures the potential difference (p.d.) across the LDR
Suggest a suitable material for the bar
Fig. 7.2 shows the bar viewed from above
On Fig. 7.2, draw at least six field lines to show the pattern and direction of the magnetic field surrounding the bar
The resistance of the variable resistor increases
Explain what happens to the magnetic field surrounding the bar and state how the pattern of field lines that represents the field changes
The right-hand end of the bar is the S pole
A square coil of many turns is placed close to the bar. Fig. 7.3 shows the plane of the square coil parallel to the flat circular surface at the right-hand end of the bar
The resistance of the variable resistor is alternately increased and decreased
Explain what happens in the wires of the square coil
A solid bar is inside a copper solenoid. Fig. 7.1 shows that the copper solenoid is connected in series with a battery and a variable resistor
The device shown in Fig. 7.1 is an electromagnet
Using the symbols shown in Fig. 8.1, draw a diagram to show the number of electrons, neutrons and protons in a neutral atom of carbon-14 and how they are arranged
symbols:
electron
neutron
proton
Describe how the composition of a neutral atom of carbon-14 is different from the composition of a neutral atom of nitrogen-14 ( \(^{14}_{7}\mathrm{N}\) )
State the name of a particle that is identical to a beta-particle
Describe the change that takes place in carbon-14 as a beta-particle is emitted
Carbon-14 decays by beta \((\beta)\) emission
The half-life of carbon-14 is 5700 years
A very old object is made of wood. It contains \(1.2 \times 10^{11}\) atoms of carbon-14. When it was manufactured, it contained \(9.6 \times 10^{11}\) atoms of carbon-14
Determine the time that has passed since it was manufactured
time passed =   .........
The nuclide notation for the radioactive isotope carbon-14 is \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm{C}\)
State what a galaxy is
The Milky Way has a diameter that is approximately equal to 100 000 light-years
Determine this distance in kilometres (km)
distance =   .........  km
State one observation that allows the speed at which a galaxy is moving away to be determined
State one different observation that is used to determine the distance to a far galaxy
State how the speeds of galaxies and their distances from the Earth are related
The best estimate for the Hubble constant \(H_0\) is \(2.2 \times 10^{- 18}\) per second
Use this value to calculate an estimate for the age of the Universe
age of the Universe =   .........  \(s\)
Astronomers determine the speed and distance from the Earth of a far galaxy that is moving away from the Earth
The Milky Way is the galaxy in which the Solar System is located
